newsitem.title: INDIA: India's oil import bill to rise to $9 bln in 96/97.
newsitem.headline: India's oil import bill to rise to $9 bln in 96/97.

text.p: India's oil import bill in 1996/97 (April-March) is likely to go up to $9.0 billion against an earlier estimate of $7.6 billion, Press Trust of India (PTI) said on Monday.
"The oil import bill is likely to increase to $9.0 billion as against the provision of $7.6 billion," PTI quoted Finance Minister P. Chidambaram as saying in the upper house.
The oil import bill is seen increasing as a result of higher world oil prices and lower domestic production.
India imports some 40 percent of its oil needs. This cost around $6.5 billion in 1995/96, accounting for just over 20 percent of India's total import bill.
Chidambaram said oil output for the current fiscal year would be lower than projections made three months ago. The finance minister did not give the output projections.
The minister justified an increase in domestic oil prices of about 20 percent in July, saying the oil import bill would have been worse if prices had not been raised.
